title: NGDocs — Monday Kickoff Work Items
notes: This is an initial planning artifact. File paths are intentional placeholders and may change.
Non-breaking requirement: leave /docs untouched; all new work lives under /NGDocs.
Local-only: Angular SPA + json-server + Express API (mandatory for SQLite access).
No .NET web apps for NGDocs.

workItems.title: Repo: Add NGDocs folder scaffold (non-breaking)
workItems.summary: Create NGDocs as a sibling folder to docs, with an initial skeleton for app/server/data and placeholder README.
workItems.iNeed: a clean NGDocs scaffold beside docs
workItems.soThat: we can start building a local-only UI without touching existing docs.
acceptance: A new /NGDocs folder exists beside /docs.
No changes are required in /docs to build or run NGDocs.
README explains intended architecture at a high level.
notes: Keep paths and wording aligned to the Monday prompt.
Avoid adding implementation complexity; this is structure only.

workItems.title: Dev UX: Add npm dev script to run Angular + json-server + Express via concurrently
workItems.summary: Define package.json scripts so one command starts the full local toolchain.
workItems.iNeed: one command to start the local UI and APIs
workItems.soThat: I can run the stack consistently without manual steps.
acceptance: npm run dev starts Angular dev server, json-server, and Express API.
Ports are documented in NGDocs/README.md.
If any process fails to start, the console output makes it obvious.
notes: Prefer distinct ports (e.g., Angular 4200, json-server 3002, Express 3100).
Use concurrently with readable names.

workItems.title: Angular: Create SPA with Bootstrap and base layout (nav + content)
workItems.summary: Create the Angular application under NGDocs/app with a shared layout and navigation.
workItems.iNeed: a consistent UI shell and navigation
workItems.soThat: I can move between docs and tools without leaving the SPA.
acceptance: Bootstrap is installed and applied to the base layout.
A top nav or side nav exists with links to Index, Getting Started, Troubleshooting, WorkItemsBoard.
SPA routes render without full page reload.
notes: Keep it simple: Bootstrap layout, no fancy state management yet.
No DB dependence for initial pages.

workItems.title: Angular Pages: Add Index, Getting Started, Troubleshooting, WorkItemsBoard routes
workItems.summary: Implement initial routes and placeholder page components for the four required pages.
workItems.iNeed: stable pages for the documentation portal
workItems.soThat: NGDocs is usable even before the DB features are implemented.
acceptance: Each route loads a page with a clear heading and placeholder content.
No console errors in the browser when navigating between pages.
notes: These pages can be content placeholders for now.

workItems.title: Docs Display: Render existing docs HTML pages inside NGDocs (display-first)
workItems.summary: Show GettingStarted/Troubleshooting/WorkItemsBoard content from docs without altering docs.
workItems.iNeed: NGDocs to display the existing docs content
workItems.soThat: we can keep docs authoritative while experimenting with a SPA shell.
acceptance: NGDocs can display the existing docs content without requiring edits to /docs.
If docs content cannot be loaded, the UI shows a friendly fallback message.
notes: Approach may be: copy static HTML into NGDocs assets, or fetch via local server; choose simplest local-dev method.
This work item is intentionally flexible; document the chosen approach in NGDocs/README.md.

workItems.title: json-server: Add work items dataset and serve it locally
workItems.summary: Create a db.json (or similar) for json-server containing WorkItems collection matching the schema used in GraphLib docs.
workItems.iNeed: a local API for work items
acceptance: json-server runs and exposes /workItems endpoints.
At least 5 sample work items exist, including the provided example shape.
README documents the port and endpoint URLs.
notes: Keep the schema stable and consistent with the example.
Do not implement editing in Phase 1 unless explicitly requested.

workItems.title: WorkItemsBoard UI: Display work items from json-server (read-only)
workItems.summary: Fetch WorkItems from json-server and render a list + detail view.
workItems.iNeed: to see the work items board in NGDocs
workItems.soThat: I can browse planned work without opening raw JSON files.
acceptance: Work items load from json-server and render in a readable list.
Selecting an item shows the full details including acceptance criteria and files.
If the API is down, show a friendly error message.
notes: Start simple: plain list + filtering by project/type/tag later.
DataTables can be deferred; don’t block progress on it.

workItems.title: Express API: Create local-only server skeleton for SQLite access (mandatory for DB features)
workItems.summary: Scaffold an Express server that will provide HTTP endpoints for SQLite operations. No UI changes required yet beyond status wiring.
workItems.iNeed: a local Express API that can open the SQLite DB file
workItems.soThat: the Angular SPA can browse/edit the DB (browser cannot read local files directly).
acceptance: Express server starts on a documented port.
GET /api/db/status returns dbSelected, path, and exists=true|false based on selection.
CORS configured for local Angular dev server.
notes: This is mandatory for DB browsing/editing; Angular cannot open filesystem DB paths.
SQLite library choice can be documented (better-sqlite3 or sqlite3).

workItems.title: DB Selector UI: Debug/Release radio selection and always-show selected path
workItems.summary: Add a DB selection UI element in NGDocs. The selection is explicit and the full path is always visible.
workItems.iNeed: to explicitly choose Debug or Release DB
workItems.soThat: there is no ambiguity about which GraphLib.db the UI is using.
acceptance: UI provides Debug/Release selection with the exact path displayed.
Selection is stored for the session (optional: persist in localStorage).
If selected DB does not exist, UI clearly shows 'Database not found' and disables DB nav.
notes: No auto-detection logic; user must choose.
Paths are fixed to the two known locations.

workItems.title: Express API: List tables and browse table rows (read-only)
workItems.summary: Provide endpoints to list tables and return paged rows for a selected table.
workItems.iNeed: to browse SQLite tables from the UI
workItems.soThat: I can inspect settings, runs, events, and metrics without a separate SQLite tool.
acceptance: GET /api/db/tables returns table names.
GET /api/db/table/:name returns paged rows and column metadata.
If DB is missing, endpoints return a clear error response.
notes: Return column names/types if feasible to help the UI render.

workItems.title: DB Browser UI: Tables list and row viewer (read-only)
workItems.summary: Angular UI for listing tables and showing rows for a selected table. Editing comes later.
workItems.soThat: I can view table data without leaving the NGDocs UI.
acceptance: Tables are listed and selectable.
Rows display in a readable table with paging.
If DB is missing, the DB page remains visible but explains why browsing is disabled.
notes: DataTables integration can be optional; start with a basic Bootstrap table.

workItems.title: Express API: Row update endpoint (CRUD without writing SQL)
workItems.summary: Add a primary-key update endpoint to support UI editing without SQL queries.
workItems.iNeed: to edit DB rows safely through the UI
workItems.soThat: I can update AppSettings and other tables without opening SQLite tools or writing SQL.
acceptance: POST /api/db/table/:name/update accepts pk column + pk value + changed fields.
Endpoint returns success/failure and updated row (or rowcount).
Updates are restricted to an allowlist of tables (initially AppSettings, Ref* optional).
notes: Define a conservative allowlist to avoid accidental corruption.
Editing EventLogs is discouraged.

workItems.title: DB Editing UI: Modal editor for allowlisted tables
workItems.summary: Add UI editing via modal forms (preferred over inline cell editing).
workItems.iNeed: a straightforward UI for editing records
workItems.soThat: I can manage settings without writing SQL.
acceptance: From a table view, a user can open a modal to edit a row.
Save sends update request and refreshes the row view.
UI clearly indicates which tables are editable vs read-only.
notes: DataTables Editor is paid; avoid it. Use Bootstrap modal and basic forms.

workItems.title: Reports: Add Chart.js visualizations for extension and conversion metrics
workItems.summary: Add a Reports page that visualizes extension counts and conversion success/failure using Chart.js.
workItems.iNeed: quick visual insights into conversions and file types
workItems.soThat: I can understand behavior without running SQL queries.
acceptance: Charts render using Chart.js with data pulled from the Express API.
At least one chart: top source extensions (ConversionMetrics).
If DB is missing, report page explains why charts are unavailable.
notes: Reports can start minimal and grow over time.

workItems.title: Advanced: SQL query runner endpoint (SELECT by default)
workItems.summary: Provide a safe SQL query endpoint for advanced users, defaulting to SELECT-only mode.
workItems.iNeed: an optional SQL runner for inspection
workItems.soThat: I can debug without leaving the NGDocs UI.
acceptance: POST /api/sql/run executes SELECT queries and returns results.
Writes are blocked unless explicitly enabled by a config toggle.
Query errors return clear messages without crashing the server.
notes: This is optional and should be treated as advanced tooling.

workItems.title: Docs: Add NGDocs living-manual page explaining local-only architecture and DB requirement
workItems.summary: Add a docs page describing NGDocs purpose, local-only constraints, Debug/Release DB selection, and why Express is mandatory for SQLite access.
workItems.iNeed: documentation explaining why NGDocs requires Express for SQLite
workItems.soThat: nobody wastes time trying to make Angular read local DB paths directly.
acceptance: Docs page clearly states Angular cannot read local SQLite files directly.
Docs page lists the two DB paths and the explicit selection model.
Docs page explains that the WorkItemsBoard uses json-server.
notes: Non-breaking: do not modify existing docs pages; just add a new one.
